key_points: Turbulence Reporting Criteria Turbulence remains an important operational factor at all levels but particularly above FL150
The best information on turbulence is obtained from pilots’ Special Aircraft Observations
All pilots encountering turbulence are requested to report time, location, level, intensity and aircraft type to the ATS Unit with whom they are in radio contact
learning.explanation: Turbulence Reporting Criteria Turbulence remains an important operational factor at all levels but particularly above FL150. The best information on turbulence is obtained from pilots’ Special Aircraft Observations. All pilots encountering turbulence are requested to report time, location, level, intensity and aircraft type to the ATS Unit with whom they are in radio contact. High level turbulence (normally above FL150 not associated with cumuliform cloud, including thunderstorms) should be reported as TURB, preceded by the appropriate intensity or preceded by Light or Moderate Chop. (Note: EASA still refer to clear air turbulence as CAT.) >Intensity: LIGHT Aircraft Reaction (transport size aircraft): Turbulence that momentarily causes slight, erratic changes in altitude and/or attitude (pitch, roll, yaw). IAS fluctuates 5 - 15 kt. (<0.5 g at the aircraft’s center of gravity) Report as ‘Light Turbulence’. Turbulence that causes slight, rapid and somewhat rhythmic bumpiness without appreciable changes in altitude or attitude. No IAS fluctuations. Report as ‘Light Chop’. Reaction Inside Aircraft: Occupants may feel a slight strain against seat belts or shoulder straps. Unsecured objects may be displaced slightly. Food service may be conducted and little or no difficulty is encountered in walking. >Intensity: MODERATE Aircraft Reaction (transport size aircraft): Turbulence that is similar to light Turbulence but of greater intensity. Changes in altitude and/or attitude occur but the aircraft remains in positive control at all times. IAS fluctuates 15 - 25 kt. (0.5 - 1.0 g at the aircraft’s center of gravity). Report as ‘Moderate Turbulence’. Turbulence that is similar to Light Chop but of greater intensity. It causes rapid bumps or jolts without appreciable changes in altitude or attitude. IAS may fluctuate slightly. Report as ‘Moderate Chop’. Reaction Inside Aircraft: Occupants feel definite strains against seat belts or shoulder straps. Unsecured objects are dislodged. Food service and walking are difficult. >Intensity: SEVERE Aircraft Reaction (transport size aircraft): Turbulence that causes large, abrupt changes in altitude and/or attitude. Aircraft may be momentarily out of control. IAS fluctuates more than 25 kt. (>1.0 g at the aircraft’s center of gravity). Report as ‘Severe Turbulence’. Reaction Inside Aircraft: Occupants are forced violently against seat belts or shoulder straps. Unsecured objects are tossed about. Food service and walking impossible. Note 1: Pilots should report location(s), time(s) (UTC), incidence, intensity, whether in or near clouds, altitude(s) and type of aircraft. All locations should be readily identifiable. Turbulence reports should be made when moderate/severe turbulence is encountered, or on request. Note 2: "The turbulence is of a small scale" refers to turbulence generated by "small-scale" wind velocity gradients around the jet stream, typically occurring within hundreds of meters or less. This turbulence occurs when rapidly moving air encounters much slower air in close proximity.

learning.explanation: ICE CRYSTAL ICING Ice crystals phenomenon has only recently been identified as a serious threat to turbine engines. Ice crystals previously were thought to be harmless to airplanes because they will not adhere to the external airframe, and will simply bounce off the airframe without accreting. Nowadays, researchers believe that ice crystals can partially melt, due to compression effects, as they pass through the engine fan section, enter the engine core and create a film of moisture on relatively warm surfaces, such as the forward stator vanes. The moisture traps additional ice crystals, and, eventually, the ice buildup is shed into the compressor, causing the engine to surge and stall and possibly the combustor, causing a flameout.

key_points: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds

In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface
learning.explanation: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -15ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Note: You are least likely to encounter icing in high clouds, because these clouds consist of ice crystals and this already-frozen moisture will not adhere to your airframe. Icing might also occur as a mixture of both rime and clear. learning.explanation: Pools of cold air often form in topographic depressions, such as a valleys or basins, filled with cold air. The cold air is heavy and settles to the bottom of the depression. This air can remain stagnant, trapped by the surrounding higher terrain, resulting in long periods of poor air quality and fog, depending on the sources of pollution and amount of moisture in the air, respectively. Where the temperature increases with an increase in height, then we have what is called an inversion: vertical mixing is inhibited and below an inversion the wind speed will be light with a significantly different direction to the much stronger wind above the inversion. Hence windshear will occur at the inversion. An aircraft climbing or descending through the inversion will experience a rapid change in speed and direction giving, possibly, moderate to severe turbulence. Note: The learning objectives do not give this a specific name, and just refer to it as a valley inversion. There is another type of weather phenomenon called a cold-air drop, which is cold air high up in the atmosphere.

content.question: A wide body aircraft takes off on a clear night in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Shortly after take-off the aircraft's rate of climb drops to zero. This can be due to:

key_points: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear
Temperature inversion is defined as a condition where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude
Strong inversions are known to happen in desert areas, such as Saudi Arabia, where the surface will heat up quickly during the day and cool off rapidly at night
learning.explanation: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear. Temperature inversion is defined as a condition where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude. Strong inversions are known to happen in desert areas, such as Saudi Arabia, where the surface will heat up quickly during the day and cool off rapidly at night. Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light, and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above. This wind shear can cause airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion. - Depending on the direction that the pilot decides to take off, the wind shift, at the top of the inversion, may change the headwind into a tailwind => which causes IAS to decrease - leading to a decrease in Rate of Climb. The fluctuation in airspeed can also induce a stall precariously close to the ground. - Furthermore, all performance is based on density altitude and temperature is a key factor. The higher the temperature, the higher the density altitude, the thinner the air and the less performance from your engines (and wings, etc). Since, as we climb through an inversion, temperature increases with an increase in height => we will experience a decreases aircrafts performance leading to a decrease in thrust and lift, as we climb into warmer and less dense air - which reduces the aircraft's rate of climb.

learning.explanation: In the standard atmosphere temperature decreases with altitude. We can think of an inversion as a "Tupperware lid" for the atmosphere - it limits the upward movement of air from lower parts of the atmosphere (inhbits vertical mixing). Characteristics: Tornadoes are associated with Cumulonimbus and large Cumulus clouds. The highest incidence is in the southern states of the USA (tornado alley) in the spring and early summer - very warm air from the Gulf of Mexico, moving north, meets relatively cold air coming from the northwest - which gives massive instability and the windshear required. They can last from several seconds up to (roughly) 30 minutes - however, most tornadoes last less than 10 minutes Its speed of movement usually ranges from 20 - 40 kts and may have rotational speeds in excess of 200 kt. Lightning typically strikes a relatively sharp edge of a plane, like a wingtip or nose, and the current exits via the tail - becoming part of the lightning trajectory. key_points: If flying around mountains, be extra cautious
The air being lifted up the mountain slopes by the wind (called orographic lifting) causes icing to be more intense than it is usual under identical conditions over low, flat terrain
It is known to produce moderate to severe icing conditions
learning.explanation: If flying around mountains, be extra cautious. The air being lifted up the mountain slopes by the wind (called orographic lifting) causes icing to be more intense than it is usual under identical conditions over low, flat terrain. It is known to produce moderate to severe icing conditions. The lifting of the cold unstable by the mountains results in the formation of more-or-less continuous supercooled clouds. Also, the orographically-induced updrafts permit the air to support larger cloud droplets than otherwise, so that the icing is more intense. As mentioned above, the additional lifting action (orographic) will support larger super-cooled water droplets which will increase the severity of the icing (moderate to severe). content.question: Which condition results in the worst ice build up?

key_points: Structural Icing: It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
Wings that are thin or have sharp leading edges are more efficient ice collectors
For this reason, smaller, thin airfoils may accrete more ice faster than larger, thick airfoils
learning.explanation: Structural Icing: It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. Wings that are thin or have sharp leading edges are more efficient ice collectors. For this reason, smaller, thin airfoils may accrete more ice faster than larger, thick airfoils. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -10ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. ⇒ Therefore, severe icing accretion is most likely to occur in thin aerofoils and in the presence of large supercooled water droplets.

learning.explanation: LIGHTNING As a towering cumulus develops, a large electrical charge separation builds up within the cloud. Lighting results when this electrical charge becomes strong enough to jump from the cloud to the ground, to another cloud, or to an opposite electrical charge within the same cloud. In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground. When the opposite charges build up enough, this insulating capacity of the air breaks down and there is a rapid discharge of electricity that we know as lightning. Types of lightning: Intra-Cloud lightning: The most common type of lightning. It happens inside the cloud, jumping between different charge regions in the cloud. Cloud-to-air lightning: Referring to a discharge (or a portion of a discharge) jumping from a cloud into clear air. This happens when negative charged air particles become attracted to positive charges within a cloud. Cloud-to-cloud lightning: Happens when a negatively charged cloud finds a positively charged cloud and opposites attract. The discharge travels from cloud to cloud. Cloud-to-ground lightning: Occurs between the cloud and the ground.

A microburst could also be expected in this region. "(5) lightning; (3) gust front; (1) windshear." Point 5 could experience some lightning through the region, from the cloud to the ground (or vice-versa), but point 3 is the core of the storm, not the gust front. content.question: During the life cycle of a thunderstorm, which stage is characterized predominantly by downdrafts?

key_points: A typical airmass thunderstorm consists of three states – initial stage (cumulus stage), Mature stage and Dissipating stage
CUMULUS STAGE/INITIAL STAGE Lifting action initiates the vertical movement of air Because of the strong updrafts (as great as 3000 ft/min), precipitation usually does not fall
Instead, the water droplets or ice crystals rise and fall within the cloud, growing larger with each cycle
learning.explanation: A typical airmass thunderstorm consists of three states – initial stage (cumulus stage), Mature stage and Dissipating stage. CUMULUS STAGE/INITIAL STAGE Lifting action initiates the vertical movement of air Because of the strong updrafts (as great as 3000 ft/min), precipitation usually does not fall. Instead, the water droplets or ice crystals rise and fall within the cloud, growing larger with each cycle. The cloud reaches the mature stage in about 15 minutes. => This stage is characterized by continuous updrafts. MATURE STAGE As the water droplets in the cloud grow too large to be supported by the updrafts, precipitation begins to fall. This creates a downward motion in the surrounding air and signals the beginning of this stage. The down-rushing air spreads outward at the surface, producing a sharp drop in temperature, a rise in pressure, strong gusty surface winds and turbulent conditions. Within the thunderstorm cloud, the strongest turbulence occurs in the shear between the updrafts and downdrafts (below the cloud) As the thunderstorm advances, a rolling, turbulent, circular shaped cloud might form at the lower leading edge of the cloud => this is called a roll cloud. It can last up to 30 min => Thunderstorms reach their greatest intensity during the mature stage (which is signaled by the beginning of precipitation at the surface). DISSIPATING STAGE As the mature stage progresses, more and more air aloft is disturbed by the falling drops. Eventually the downdrafts begin to spread out within the cell – taking the place of the weakening updrafts. During this stage the upper level winds often blow the top of the cloud downwind, creating the familiar anvil shape. => Thunderstorms reach this stage when downdrafts become the dominant air movement within this cell.

When this happens, the water vapour in the surrounding, warmer air touches the aircraft and will sublimate (the actual process is called deposition, however, EASA use the word sublimation) straight onto the freezing cold wing, forming a frost we know as hoar frost

key_points: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals
At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology)
Engine surfaces and pitot tubes are affected
learning.explanation: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals. At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology). Engine surfaces and pitot tubes are affected. Several engine power-loss and damage events have occurred in convective weather above the altitudes typically associated with icing conditions. Research has shown that strong convective weather (thunderstorm activity) can lift high concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where it can freeze into very small ice crystal. The main risk of encountering high crystal concentrations appears to be downwind from the tops of large areas of convective cloud - the area where the visible anvil shape is seen when viewed from a distance. Normal thunderstorm avoidance procedures may help pilots avoid regions of high ice crystal content. These avoidance procedures include: Avoiding flying in visible moisture over storm cells. Visible moisture at high altitude must be considered a threat since intense storm cells may produce high concentrations of ice crystals at cruise altitude. Flying upwind of storms when possible. Using the radar antenna tilt function to scan the reflectivity of storms ahead. Assess the height of the storms. Recognize that heavy rain below the freezing level typically indicates high concentrations of ice crystals above. Avoiding storm reflectivity by 20 nautical miles has been commonly used as a recommended distance from convection. This may not be sufficient for avoidance of high concentrations of ice crystals, as they are not visible on airborne radar.

The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled

learning.explanation: Freezing Rain occurs when precipitation, in the form of rain, passes from a warm air mass into a relative cold air mass of an air temperature less than 0°C. The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled. It can cause significant accumulations of Clear Ice. Given the scenario of encountering stratus clouds generating freezing rain at minimum safe altitude on your route, the best course of action would be to climb to a flight level above the cloud top. Climbing above the cloud tops would help you avoid the freezing rain, as this precipitation typically occurs below the cloud tops where supercooled water droplets exist. Deviating from the planned route (option b) might also be a viable option if climbing is not possible, but flying across (option c) or below (option d) the freezing rain is not advisable due to the significant hazards posed by icing conditions.

content.question: Clouds will mainly consist of supercooled water droplets when the temperature is:

key_points: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds

In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface
learning.explanation: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -15ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Note: You are least likely to encounter icing in high clouds, because these clouds consist of ice crystals and this already-frozen moisture will not adhere to your airframe. Icing might also occur as a mixture of both rime and clear. TEMPERATURE RANGE TYPE OF ICING RIME ICE (Small supercooled water droplets Stratiform clouds) 0ºC TO -15ºC -15ºC TO -30ºC Expect moderate icing Expect light icing CLEAR ICE (Large supercooled water droplets Cumuliform clouds) 0ºC TO -15ºC May be found in CB’s at -25ºC Expect severe icing

The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled

key_points: LIGHTNING As a towering cumulus develops, a large electrical charge separation builds up within the cloud
Lighting results when this electrical charge becomes strong enough to jump from the cloud to the ground, to another cloud, or to an opposite electrical charge within the same cloud
In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground
learning.explanation: LIGHTNING As a towering cumulus develops, a large electrical charge separation builds up within the cloud. Lighting results when this electrical charge becomes strong enough to jump from the cloud to the ground, to another cloud, or to an opposite electrical charge within the same cloud. In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground. When the opposite charges build up enough, this insulating capacity of the air breaks down and there is a rapid discharge of electricity that we know as lightning. Types of lightning: Intra-Cloud lightning: The most common type of lightning. It happens inside the cloud, jumping between different charge regions in the cloud. It lights up the cloud. Cloud-to-air lightning: Referring to a discharge (or a portion of a discharge) jumping from a cloud into clear air. This happens when negative charged air particles become attracted to positive charges within a cloud. Cloud-to-cloud lightning: Happens when a negatively charged cloud finds a positively charged cloud and opposites attract. The discharge travels from cloud to cloud. Cloud-to-ground lightning: Flows from the cloud to the ground. Often has downward "branches" or "forks" which come off at angles and discharge into the surrounding air. Ground-to-cloud lightning: Also known as upward lightning, and has the opposite direction of charge from the cloud-to-ground lightning above. The lightning flows upwards, and may have a few small upwards branches, but is mostly made up of just one path. This image is good enough to see that the lightning is cloud-to-air, as it comes out of the cloud in the very bright region, and the forks spread out and disappear into the air, not going into any other clouds.

key_points: In the standard atmosphere temperature decreases with altitude
Where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude (in the troposphere), then we have what is called an inversion
We can think of an inversion as a "Tupperware lid" for the atmosphere - it limits the upward movement of air from lower parts of the atmosphere (inhbits vertical mixing)
learning.explanation: In the standard atmosphere temperature decreases with altitude. Where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude (in the troposphere), then we have what is called an inversion. We can think of an inversion as a "Tupperware lid" for the atmosphere - it limits the upward movement of air from lower parts of the atmosphere (inhbits vertical mixing). Consequently, air pollutants, smoke, and dust aren't able to be dispersed throughout the atmosphere. This accumulation of particulates can cause reduced visibility below the inversion. With regards to this question, as we have discussed, as we climb through an inversion, temperature increases with an increase in height => Thrust and lift will decrease as the aircraft climbs into warmer and less dense air. Air pollutants, smoke, and dust will not disperse vertically, instead they are trapped below the inversion - resulting in a deteriorated visibility => Therefore, visibility improves above the inversion.

) The triggers/lifting forces are: Convection, Orographic uplift, Convergence, Frontal uplift With regards to this question, the above conditions are fullfiled as described below: Maritime air (which is already moist) advecting over another moist surface (water) => will produce plenty of moisture to fuel the development of a Thunderstorm
learning.explanation: Thunderstorms (TS) occur in well developed cumulonimbus (Cb) cloud, though not all Cbs produce thunderstorms. Three basic ingredients are required for a thunderstorm to form: Sufficient water vapour to form and maintain the cloud; Unstable air (an ELR greater than the SALR); and A lifting mechanism/trigger (action to produce early saturation, thus enhancing instability.) The triggers/lifting forces are: Convection, Orographic uplift, Convergence, Frontal uplift With regards to this question, the above conditions are fullfiled as described below: Maritime air (which is already moist) advecting over another moist surface (water) => will produce plenty of moisture to fuel the development of a Thunderstorm. key_points: A katabatic wind is caused by a ﬂow of cold air down a hill or mountain side at night, when the highlands radiate heat and are cooled
The air in contact with the higher-level ground is also cooled, and it becomes denser than the air at the same elevation but away from the slope; it, therefore, begins to flow downhill

learning.explanation: A katabatic wind is caused by a ﬂow of cold air down a hill or mountain side at night, when the highlands radiate heat and are cooled. The air in contact with the higher-level ground is also cooled, and it becomes denser than the air at the same elevation but away from the slope; it, therefore, begins to flow downhill. The katabatic eﬀect is most marked if the mountain side is snow covered, if the sky is clear to assist radiation and if the PG is slack. In valleys, inversions are also called cold-air pools and form as a result of both cooling of the ground due to long-wave radiation and nocturnal down-slope winds (Katabatic winds). The colder air which flows down the valley walls may “collect” at the bottom of the valley, creating a cold pool of air near the surface and low temperatures on the ground. They usually extend from the bottom of the valley up to the boundary-layer top. In winter, inversions can last for a few days to several weeks, being triggered and maintained by anticyclonic conditions at synoptic scale => Because the dense air is not able to rise and disperse, near-ground air pollution, haze, and possibly even fog, visibility inside the cold valley pool is generally not very good.

learning.explanation: THUNDERSTORMS are classified as: Air mass type (heat thunderstorms) - more common in summer time. Frontal type - more common in winter time, usually formed in a line at a cold front or occlusion and often accompanied by a squall line. Frontal Thunderstorms are the fastest moving. Air mass thunderstorm is generally a thunderstorm which is not associated with a front or other type of synoptic-scale forcing mechanism. Rather air mass thunderstorms are associated with warm, moist and thus unstable air masses in the summer months. They develop locally during the afternoon or late in the day in response to insolation through convective heating from the surface. Thus they are also known as single-cell thunderstorms. Typically they do not persist very long - usually an hour or so - and dissipate rather quickly after sunset. They move slowly and do not produce severe weather.

content.question: Approximately, how much time will it take for a CB cloud to develop to the mature stage?

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.09.04.02.01: Assess the average duration of thunderstorms and their different stages. A typical airmass thunderstorm consists of three states – Initial/Developing stage, Mature stage and Dissipating stage. INITIAL/DEVELOPING STAGE Lifting action initiates the vertical movement of air Because of the strong updrafts (as great as 3000 ft/min), precipitation does not fall. Instead, the water droplets or ice crystals rise and fall within the cloud, growing larger with each cycle. The cloud will reach the mature stage in about 15-20 minutes. => This stage is characterized by continuous updrafts. The cloud is a towering cumulus during this stage MATURE STAGE As the water droplets in the cloud grow too large to be supported by the updrafts, precipitation begins to fall. This creates a downward motion in the surrounding air and signals the beginning of this stage. The down-rushing air spreads outward at the surface, producing a sharp drop in temperature, a rise in pressure, strong gusty surface winds and turbulent conditions. Within the thunderstorm cloud, the strongest turbulence occurs in the shear between the updrafts and downdrafts (below the cloud) As the thunderstorm advances, a rolling, turbulent, circular shaped cloud might form at the lower leading edge of the cloud => this is called a roll cloud. It can last up to 30 minutes (in a single cell). => Thunderstorms reach their greatest intensity during the mature stage (which is signaled by the beginning of precipitation at the surface). DISSIPATING STAGE As the mature stage progresses, more and more air aloft is disturbed by the falling drops. Eventually the downdrafts begin to spread out within the cell – taking the place of the weakening updrafts. During this stage the upper level winds often blow the top of the cloud downwind, creating the familiar anvil shape. => Thunderstorms reach this stage when downdrafts become the dominant air movement within this cell.

Positive charge in the storm top flows upwards into the ionosphere, causing it to gain a net positive charge
learning.explanation: THUNDERSTORMS Each storm separates positive and negative charge. Positive charge is typically transferred towards the storm top and negative charge accumulates towards the bottom. Positive charge in the storm top flows upwards into the ionosphere, causing it to gain a net positive charge. At the same time, negative charge from the base of the storm is transferred down to Earth’s surface in lightning and negatively charged rain. learning.explanation: Let's keep it simple, as the day wears on, it starts to get warmer and sunny. Air that is heated at the Earth’s surface will expand, become less dense and rise. key_points: A katabatic wind is caused by a ﬂow of cold air down a hill or mountain side at night, when the highlands radiate heat and are cooled
The air in contact with the higher-level ground is also cooled, and it becomes denser than the air at the same elevation but away from the slope; it, therefore, begins to flow downhill

learning.explanation: A katabatic wind is caused by a ﬂow of cold air down a hill or mountain side at night, when the highlands radiate heat and are cooled. The air in contact with the higher-level ground is also cooled, and it becomes denser than the air at the same elevation but away from the slope; it, therefore, begins to flow downhill. The katabatic eﬀect is most marked if the mountain side is snow covered, if the sky is clear to assist radiation and if the PG is slack. Speeds average 10 kt and the ﬂow of cold air into the valley helps frost and fog to form. In valleys, inversions are also called cold-air pools and form as a result of both cooling of the ground due to long-wave radiation and nocturnal down-slope winds (Katabatic winds). The colder air which flows down the valley walls may “collect” at the bottom of the valley, creating a cold pool of air near the surface and low temperatures on the ground. They usually extend from the bottom of the valley up to the boundary-layer top. In winter, inversions can last for a few days to several weeks, being triggered and maintained by anticyclonic conditions at synoptic scale

learning.explanation: Note: This question is not exact, and we have had varying feedback about the options present in the exam. Please let us know if you see this in the exam, and anything you can remember about it, thank you! A squall line is a narrow band of active thunderstorms that normally contains very severe weather. Although it often forms 50 to 200 miles ahead of a fast-moving cold front, the existence of a front is not necessary for a squall line to form. Obviously, with so many thunderstorms, the weather around a squall line can be very bad. This includes widespread turbulence, of course moderate to severe inside the clouds themselves, but also some intense clear air turbulence (CAT) around, above, and underneath the squall line. Squall lines should be avoided by an even larger margin than isolated CBs. As for the other answers: In a cold occlusion, there is usually turbulence within the clouds and precipitation, but not always clear air turbulence around (it very much depends on the altitude you fly through it, and the conditions of the day), whereas squall lines always contain many CBs so definitely do provide some CAT. A warm high would be a stable portion of air, so unlikely to provide much turbulence at all. With calm winds (no sea breeze, etc), a coastline could cause some turbulence due to changing thermals between land and sea, but it wouldn't usually be much, and certainly not as much as around a squall line.

Blowing snow is the meteorological term for any loose snow lifted from the ground surface and suspended by strong winds to a height of 2 m (6 ft) or more above the surface (higher than drifting snow), and blown about in such quantities that horizontal visibility is reduced to less than 11 km. Blowing snow can be falling snow or snow that already accumulated but is picked up and blown about by strong winds. It is one of the classic requirements for a blizzard. As an obstruction to vision, it is encoded as BLSN as an obstruction to vision in a METAR report. Concerning visibility in snow, we can expect visibility in the range of approximately 1 000 m in moderate snowfall and a significant reduction of visibility in heavy snowfall (50 m - 200 m). Drifting snow and Blowing snow can further reduce the visibility to a minimum of 1 m.

content.question: At what levels does icing predominantly form in a CB cloud?

options.A: Predominantly in the middle section of the CB.
options.B: Icing is very rare in a CB.
options.C: Icing occurs equally at all the levels of the CB.
options.D: Predominantly in the top of the CB.

key_points: Airframe icing is a huge hazard to flight
In icing conditions, pilots have to be very careful
Not only does ice accretion add weight and drag to an aircraft, it also changes the shape of the wing, reducing the finely tuned lift characteristics
learning.explanation: Airframe icing is a huge hazard to flight. In icing conditions, pilots have to be very careful. Not only does ice accretion add weight and drag to an aircraft, it also changes the shape of the wing, reducing the finely tuned lift characteristics. It can also block probes and ice over ports or vanes. Airframe icing happens primarily whilst flying in an area with an air temperature just below 0ºC, and therefore with an airframe below freezing temperature. Clouds can often contain droplets of water that are below freezing temperature (0ºC), but are still in liquid form. These are called Super-Cooled Water Droplets (SCWDs). As soon as SCWDs hit a freezing airframe, they will freeze onto it. This freezing can take place a bit differently depending on the droplet size and temperature. If the droplets are large, and quite close to the freezing point, then they will release enough latent heat as they freeze, that the rest of the droplet will drip backwards over the wing and form clear ice. This is usually regarded as the most dangerous type of ice. The freezing can also happen immediately (particularly for smaller droplets at lower temperatures), and they form a white build-up on the leading edge of the wings and other surfaces, called rime ice. The worst icing happens just below 0ºC, and icing can occur down to temperatures as cold as -45ºC, but it is a gradual drop off, and you would not expect any significantly dangerous ice below -23ºC. The SCWDs rarely get much colder than this before freezing in the cloud. Convective clouds such as CBs are the worst for icing, as they can hold large droplets using their strong updrafts, and have wild temperature changes allowing large SCWDs into colder sections where an airframe would be very prone to icing. Nimbostratus clouds can also hold medium sized droplets and produce moderate icing. Inside a CB cloud, the worst icing is going to be just above the freezing level, which is usually around the middle of the cloud. At the bottom of the cloud, the temperature is above freezing, and at the top of the cloud, it is mostly just ice crystals and hail that has been thrown up there.

options.B: contains much smaller supercooled water droplets than the stratiform, hence the build-up of ice is not as rapid.
options.C: contains relatively large supercooled water droplets, which can lead to a very rapid build-up of ice.
options.D: is such that maximum ice accretion occurs near the top of the cloud.

key_points: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds

In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface
learning.explanation: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque/milky granular appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -15ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Note: You are least likely to encounter icing in high clouds, because these clouds consist of ice crystals and this already-frozen moisture will not adhere to your airframe. Icing might also occur as a mixture of both rime and clear. TEMPERATURE RANGE TYPE OF ICING RIME ICE (Small supercooled water droplets Stratiform clouds) 0ºC TO -15ºC -15ºC TO -30ºC Expect moderate icing Expect light icing CLEAR ICE (Large supercooled water droplets Cumuliform clouds) 0ºC TO -15ºC May be found in CB’s at -25ºC Expect severe icing

key_points: Mountainous areas significantly influence the weather
Generally, the higher and steeper the mountain, the greater its effect on weather
Orography enhances the updraft of air and thus enhances the development of water droplets that are large in size
learning.explanation: Mountainous areas significantly influence the weather. Generally, the higher and steeper the mountain, the greater its effect on weather. Orography enhances the updraft of air and thus enhances the development of water droplets that are large in size. As the air is forced to ascend on the upwind side of the mountain, it cools down adiabatically to its dew point. This leads to the formation of clouds, and even precipitation. Weather fronts are also modified if they reach mountainous regions. An additional mechanical lifting effect strengthens the updraft - as a result, embedded Cu and Cb clouds may form. This enhances icing, turbulence and the formation of precipitation primarily on the upwind side. Learning Objective 050.09.08.01.01: Describe the influence of mountainous area on a frontal passage.

At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology)
Several engine power-loss and damage events have occurred in convective weather above the altitudes typically associated with icing conditions
learning.explanation: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals. At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology). Several engine power-loss and damage events have occurred in convective weather above the altitudes typically associated with icing conditions. Research has shown that strong convective weather (thunderstorm activity) can lift high concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where it can freeze into very small ice crystal. Ice crystals do not adhere to cold airframe surfaces because the ice crystals bounce off. However, the crystals can partially melt and stick to relatively warm engine surfaces.

content.question: What are the conditions required for the formation of hoar frost?

options.A: Falling droplets on a surface while the air temperature is below freezing.
options.B: Falling droplets on a surface with a temperature below freezing.
options.C: The temperature of the surface is lower than the dew point of the air and this dew point is lower than 0°C.
options.D: The temperature of the surface is higher than the dew point of the air and this dew point is lower than 0°C.

key_points: HOAR FROST It occurs when a sub-zero surface comes into contact with moist air (the ambient temperature is lowered to saturation level)
It is a white crystal deposit which appears similar to frost on the ground
Hoar frost occurs in clear air
learning.explanation: HOAR FROST It occurs when a sub-zero surface comes into contact with moist air (the ambient temperature is lowered to saturation level). It is a white crystal deposit which appears similar to frost on the ground. Hoar frost occurs in clear air. Water vapour in contact with the airframe is converted to ice crystals without becoming liquid (sublimating). This whole process required the presence of another type of ice nucleus – their composition is usually inorganic (ie. Dust, soil particles). Hoar frost can occur: on the ground. This usually occurs at night and is similar to the frost which forms on a car. If frost is not removed from the wings before flight, it can cause an early airflow separation that decreases lift and increases drag. This causes the airplane to stall at a lower-than-normal angle of attack. in flight. Hoar frost can occur in flight in the following cases: If a rapid descent is made from a very cold region to a warm moist layer. If a climb is made from a temperature below 0°C through an inversion. The icing is not severe. The effects can be overcome by flying in a region where the temperature is above 0°C or by flying faster to increase the kinetic heating.

content.question: When an aircraft approaches an airport west of a mountain range amid cold and stable air conditions, with clouds forming just below the mountain tops due to a westerly wind, the critical question arises: at what location is the most severe airframe icing anticipated, given that the zero-degree isotherm aligns with the height of the ridge?

options.A: On the east side of the mountains, just above the ridge.
options.B: On the west side of the mountains, about half way up.

learning.explanation: 050.09.01.01.12: Explain the higher concentration of water drops in stratiform orographic clouds. The uplifting of air along mountain slopes by the wind, a phenomenon known as orographic lifting, intensifies icing conditions compared to identical circumstances over low, flat terrain. This process is associated with the development of moderate to severe icing conditions, with greater icing observed over ridges than valleys and on the windward side compared to the leeward side. In this particular situation, stable cold air is compelled to ascend the west slope of the mountain, resulting in the formation of a stratiform cloud just below the mountain top, and the freezing layer positioned at the mountain's peak. The highest risk of icing occurs above the freezing layer (zero-degree isotherm), where there is a high concentration of water droplets on the western side of the mountain due to the forced condensation of rising air. As elaborated earlier, this stratus cloud, formed through orographic lifting, exhibits a higher concentration of water droplets and larger droplet sizes compared to a typical stratus cloud.

content.question: Which of the following temperature ranges would be most conducive to forming carburettor ice?

key_points: Aircraft icing can be divided into two general types based on whether it affects power production or aerodynamics
Induction icing affects engine power and includes when ice forms in the carburettor venturi

learning.explanation: Aircraft icing can be divided into two general types based on whether it affects power production or aerodynamics. Induction icing affects engine power and includes when ice forms in the carburettor venturi. It can occur when the outside air temperature is between -10ºC and +30ºC and with a high relative humidity. Carburettor icing is particularly common, as the air cools down significantly inside the carburettor, not only due to the decreased static pressure in the venturi section (decreasing the temperature adiabatically) but also the evaporation of the fuel inside the carburettor, which requires latent heat input, thereby cooling the air. It is worse when the throttle is low, thereby causing the throttle butterfly valve to have only a small opening, further increasing the venturi effect. As you can see by the graph above, the worst icing happens between about -1ºC and +15°C, which is very close to the correct answer given here. Too warm, and the air won't cool down enough in the carburettor to form ice. Too cold, and there isn't usually enough water vapour in the air to develop carburettor icing.

The windshear (headwind to tailwind) may be between 50 and 90 kt

learning.explanation: Microbursts are down currents in the cloud which also move outwards by reaction from the ground, having speeds considerably in excess of 1000 feet per minute downwards (up to 6000 fpm) and 50 kt horizontally. The windshear (headwind to tailwind) may be between 50 and 90 kt. They are largely caused by descending raindrops which cool the surrounding air by evaporation, the higher density accelerating the downdraught still further. They are concentrated in a burst which is up to 4 km in horizontal length and have a lifetime of less than 5 minutes. A macroburst is a similar event but over a bigger area. Microbursts are most likely to occur in summer air mass thunderstorms in low latitude regions where surface conditions are dry. They cause extreme turbulence and severe windshear conditions. A warning sign of windshear is virga, which is streaks of precipitation from below the cloud which do not reach the ground.

content.question: What type of icing reduces visibility through an unheated windshield the most?

key_points: There are a few different types of ice that can form on an aircraft in flight
The two most common are rime ice and clear ice
RIME ICE Rime ice is an opaque, cloudy type of ice build up that usually accretes on leading edges, such as the aircraft nose, wing/tail leading edges, etc
learning.explanation: There are a few different types of ice that can form on an aircraft in flight. The two most common are rime ice and clear ice. RIME ICE Rime ice is an opaque, cloudy type of ice build up that usually accretes on leading edges, such as the aircraft nose, wing/tail leading edges, etc. It is opaque due to the air trapped inside the ice; this makes it very difficult to see through. It is normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. CLEAR ICE As you can expect from the name, clear ice is a transparent, layered form of icing, which usually runs backwards over the airframe or the wing. It is more dangerous than rime ice as it affects the aerodynamic shape of the wing more, and allows a larger ice build up, which adds weight and drag. It can also run backwards over control surfaces, freezing them in place. Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -10ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice would be much easier to see through if accreted on a windshield than the cloudy rime ice. The other types of icing that can be encountered in flight are mixed ice (a mixture of rime and clear ice) and ice crystal icing (a much rarer formation inside engines and pitot tubes from tiny ice crystals above large storms - looks like rain on a heated windshield - bounces off unheated surfaces)

learning.explanation: TORNADO is a violently rotating column of air that extends from a thunderstorm to the ground. It usually occurs as a result of vertical windshear with warm moist air at low altitude and cool dry air at high altitude, which comes from a different direction. Characteristics: Tornadoes are associated with Cumulonimbus and large Cumulus clouds. The highest incidence is in the southern states of the USA (tornado alley) in the spring and early summer - very warm air from the Gulf of Mexico, moving north, meets relatively cold air coming from the northwest - which gives massive instability and the windshear required. They can last from several seconds up to (roughly) 30 minutes - however, most tornadoes last less than 10 minutes Its speed of movement usually ranges from 20 - 40 kts and may have rotational speeds in excess of 200 kt. Averaging about 100 m in diameter (maximum of about 300 m). Within Europe tornadoes are much weaker systems whose maximum diameter is of the order of 100 m - 150 m

options.D: the development of a loss-of-energy situation, requiring a swift increase in engine power.

key_points: The rapid increase in headwind (decreased tailwind), results in a sudden increase of TAS
Consequently, lift increases and the aircraft "ballons" above the correct glide slope unless the pilot takes action
When the aircraft ballons just before the flare and the pilot takes no action => it causes the aircraft to land further down the runway
learning.explanation: The rapid increase in headwind (decreased tailwind), results in a sudden increase of TAS. Consequently, lift increases and the aircraft "ballons" above the correct glide slope unless the pilot takes action. When the aircraft ballons just before the flare and the pilot takes no action => it causes the aircraft to land further down the runway. In extreme cases, if no further action is taken to correct this, the aircarft might not have enough runway ahead to stop and may overrun from the runway surface (excursion).

content.question: Which description best describes the effect of a lightning strike on an aircraft and the consequences?

options.A: Aircraft are “Faraday`s cages” and lightning has no effect on the structure of the aircraft. However the thunder may frighten some passengers.
options.B: Water on the fuselage weakens the effect of the “Faraday`s cage” and may allow lightning to penetrate the aircrafts skin and to injure passengers.
options.C: The consequences of lightning strikes on aircraft in flight are not predictable. In many cases it results in accidents, sometimes with the total loss of the aircraft.
options.D: Most aircraft are considered to be “Faraday`s cages” and the impact of lightning strikes is minor, but in some cases structural damages may occur. The bright flash may also blind the pilot for 30 seconds or more.

key_points: LIGHTNING is a huge electrical discharge that flows between clouds, from a cloud to air, or from a cloud to the ground
It is most likely to occur within about 5000 ft of the freezing level
Temperature between +10°C and -10°C
learning.explanation: LIGHTNING is a huge electrical discharge that flows between clouds, from a cloud to air, or from a cloud to the ground. It is most likely to occur within about 5000 ft of the freezing level. Temperature between +10°C and -10°C. Lightning typically strikes a relatively sharp edge of a plane, like a wingtip or nose, and the current exits via the tail. This happens because an aircraft's fuselage, or body, acts as a Faraday cage (a container that blocks electromagnetic fields). In short, lightning strikes are not a severe problem from a safety standpoint. When air operators route around stormy areas, it is to prevent turbulence or possible external damage caused by things like hail rather than to avoid lightning. The main effects of a lightning strike are: Temporary blindness of the pilots Minor airframe damage Magnetic compasses may be seriously affected (errors of 10s of degrees have been recorded) and their information should be used with caution until they can be checked Disruption to electrical equipment
